timeline.subject: Margueritte veuve Claudin Hierosme
timeline.details: Accused presented herself before maire Zacary Ragot, accompanied by daughter Marie and son-in-law Collas Hierosme. She knew he suspected her over 2 dead horses. He said he wanted to arrest her even if it cost 100 écus. She chose to leave, renouncing citizenship and village rights, then donated all property to son-in-law and fled.

notable_quotes.speaker: Margueritte veuve Claudin Hierosme
notable_quotes.french: Messieurs puis que je voy qu'il y a partie des bourgeois d'icy qui ont soupson sur moy, et qu'ilz ne me voyent volontiers, j'ayme mieux m'en aller, et m'absenter d'icy que d'y estre a regret, et contre leur volonté, et que de me laisser tormenter (car celluy qui est pris n'a pas bon droict). Je quicte (dict elle) des maintenant à la bourgeoisie, aux droictz du village, et a tout
notable_quotes.english: Gentlemen since I see that there are some of the bourgeois here who have suspicion on me, and that they do not see me willingly, I prefer to leave, and absent myself from here than to be here with regret, and against their will, and to let myself be tormented (for he who is arrested has no good right). I renounce (she said) from now on the bourgeoisie, the rights of the village, and everything

extraction_metadata.notes: This is a fascinating case of voluntary exile. Margueritte was a healer/cunning woman known as 'la Charbonniere' who fled before trial after realizing she was under suspicion. She strategically presented herself to authorities, articulated her understanding that 'he who is arrested has no good right,' renounced her citizenship, donated her property to her son-in-law, and disappeared. The testimony reveals complex patterns: she both harmed and healed people, suggesting she was seen as having power over illness. The case of Barbe is particularly detailed, with three corroborating witnesses (Barbe's mother, husband, and mother-in-law) all testifying about the same death. Margueritte's healing practices involved milk (especially from black cows), powder, grease, and ceremonial activities (neuvaine, visiting graveyard at dawn). She was ultimately banished in absentia. Notable that she received no torture, no imprisonment, and the trial took nearly 3 years from her flight to final sentence.
